reviewText: We had watched this off DVD, but purchased it off Amazon to watch it in preparation for Malcolm McDowell's guest appearances in the just ended 2011-2012 season of CSI: Miami.  This is an interesting episode where CSI Cardoza's (Eddie Cibrian's) character's past plays a key role in solving the case before the team.  A murder with ties to a crime Cardoza had investigated during his time in LA leads to Horatio and Delco heading to LA to investigate allegations that Cardoza had not properly investigated a case and lead to a suspected murderer being found not guilty of a crime.  Horatio and Delco are able to show that Cardoza was set up in order to get the suspect off, clearing Cardoza.This episode was interesting in that it got part of the team out of Miami.  Guest star Malcolm McDowell plays yet another of the smart, creepy characters he seems to be typecast in.  As always, he plays the character so well that you hate the character's actions but love his performance.  If you're watching the 2011-2012 I highly recommend watching this episode because a confrontation between Malcolm McDowell's lawyer character and Horatio is referenced in toward the end of the 2011-2012 season whenm Malcolm McDowell's law firm sets up a branch in Miami that the CSI team runs up against.

reviewText: CSI: Miami is the best CSI in my opinion.  It gets better every season and the characters get more complex and the situations more twisted and exciting.Horatio's opening lines may be a little cheesy sometimes, but that just adds a little levity to the show, and if anyone messes with Horatio or his people, he will shoot them and talk trash afterwards.I wouldn't recommend jumping into this season if you aren't familiar with the series, start from the beginning, but if you're familiar with the show then grab this to complete your collection.

Spectacular action, some unpleasant images (corpes, decomposition) etc.  Overall I rate this as an excellent TV drama with very good writers and production staff, although filmed in California, a Miami feel to the show is also one of the characters.  Co-star Emily Procter is smart, sexy and more that able to hold her own.  One of the best shows on TV today!

reviewText: I would like to start off with the following:IF YOU DO NOT LIKE DAVID CARUSO/HORATIO CAINE, DON'T BUY IT OR WATCH IT. IF YOU DON'T LIKE CSI: MIAMI AT ALL, DON'T WATCH IT AND DON'T BUY IT.IF YOU LIKE THE SERIES AND THE CHARACTERS, YOU MIGHT WANT TO PICK THIS UP.Now, that I've clarified a few things...This is the 2nd CSI franchise and FOR ME, is slightly better than the first one, though I tend to like CSI: NY more. Here is my order: CSI: NY & CSI: Miami, the original does not interest me, can not get into it, so I don't watch it, or make a negative review about it.All said and done, this review is about the item, not the series or the season itself.This season does feature some major cast/character changes, and those die-hards who want to hold on to their attachments to certain characters will be disappointed; but the producers seem to get some of it it sorted out by the end; at least with the return of Eric Delko.I won't get into any spoilers as some might not have been able to see the entire season.I will say that the story-lines were interesting, especially the CSI Trilogy crossover which is included in this set (DISC 3) and YES, every episode is included in this season set (CSI: MIAMI "Bone Voyage"/CSI: NY "Hammer Down"/CSI "The Lost Girls") which makes this DVD set a must get for the CSI: Miami fan.Unlike with the CSI: MIAMI/NY crossovers where you had to buy both series to have them completed...you do not need to get all three series for the crossover. It appears the trilogy is included on CSI season 10, but I am not sure if it is included on CSI: NY season 6 though.I am sure if you like all three series, having all the episodes on the discs 3x seems redundant, however if you're like me and only like 1 or 2 of the franchise, it makes it easier by having them all on on particular series' DVD set. Again, it is personal preference and you might not want to spend upwards to $150 ($50 each or less with shipping) to get the trilogy completed. So this makes a good value in that sense.As far as the "product"; the case this time around is 1 piece hard plastic snap case (slightly thicker than a standard DVD case) with all the discs in "divided" flip-sections (can't really explain it any better, sorry). The episodes are listed on the DVDs as well as on the "insert" in the case.If you're a fan of the series, you'll want to add this to your collection, if not, pass it up. All in all I think the producers and the manufacturer spent their time with this and it is quite an addition to your CSI: Miami collection.
summary: CSI: Miami Season 8; not great, but pretty good
Title: N/A

reviewText: Unlike the original "C.S.I. Vegas" which keeps changing cast members, first they wrote out Jorga Fox, then axed eye candy Lauren Lee Smith, then Liz Vassey, which means I am done with that one, however this one "Miami" still retains it's original cast, & for that reason, I am still intrigued by this one, after the great 7th Season, I didn't think they would be able to top that one, but this 8th Season was just as good, Eric Delko (Adam Rodriguez) leaves briefly, but returns later in the season, this one sees some unique cases that touch on today's pop culture, there is a Miley Cyrus type episode, a triple murder involving three college students who humiliated someone, a meth lab home explosion, a dirty cop among the ranks, a trip to L.A. with an all star cast including William Forsthye(The Rock), Michael Madsen, & Malcolm McDowell, a "Mommie Dearest" type murder, & the cross-over episodes from "Vegas" & "NY", & another cliffhanger ending that will leave you scratching your head, & Eddie Cibrian (Third Watch) who I was quite impressed with, him being fired over his fling with country star Lee Ann Rimes seems stupid to me, I guess Executive Producer Ann Donahue was worried about bad press (stupid!!), despite this, it is on par with the previous seasons, however I was hoping we would see Elizabeth Berkely again as Horatio's ex & mother of his son, but she is MIA here & I was hoping we would see that killer Sarius (Kim Coates) get his, but I guess they are saving his character's demise for the end, you know they are, & David Caruso once again commands the screen with his cool presence, I still don't know why people have it in for him, so he left "NYPD Blue"...can't people just let it go??!!..anyway, this is a must have if you are a fan of this show.
summary: Still has it...has not lost it's flair!

reviewText: The first few seasons of CSI:Miami were entertaining, glitzy, and original, and are the reason I keep giving CSI:Miami another chance.  While Season 8 returns to the stronger writing/plots of the early years, it retains the poor acting, and adds in choppy production and painfully primitive special effects.  I've watched all the seasons except for 7, but this will be the last season I bother with.The acting and dialogue remain wooden-- experienced forensics experts explaining basic technique (over and over) out-loud as they work??  And the several new characters aren't well defined, other than the surly new Medical Examiner, who is perhaps the most believable of the additions.The circumstances remain often silly.  The Forensics team arrives first (before uniformed cops?  before firefighters at a fire??) Or goes in with guns drawn, without any uniformed cops?  Crime lab serves warrants?? The head of the massive crime lab personally goes on site all the time?  There's so little crime in Miami that the entire dayshift of their crime lab can go to random crime sites?  I'm willing to not fret about little things like all the scientists wearing sidearms all the time, but these are major that make it seem like children playing at policework rather than actors portraying simplified policework.There's a lot of "the killer is a blonde, you're a blonde" followed by the accused immediately confessing.Suspension of disbelief is not happening here.There's a lot of "we held you in lock up just because, now scram", unlawful search+seizure, "you're the murderer!  Prove you're not!" and other bending of legal procedure.  This stuff does happen in real life (sadly) so shouldn't be portrayed in such a cavalier manner.  When it happens to real people, it's traumatic to be locked up, or be accused of murder, or pressured by cops with the threat of arrest if you don't talk right now without a lawyer, or having your purse searched w/o a warrant but cooperating anyway because the cop has threatened to put your kid in foster care?  Yes this is fiction, but the other CSI franchises balance this much better.And OMG the special effects.  The 1990s quality superimposed graphics are horribly done.  There are terrible sequences, such as the bear charging the CSIs (really).  But they picture a gigantic grizzly (in S.Florida?!), and they cavalierly kill it with a single shot from a pistol (really?), but act surprised the shooter (Jessie) has a gun (but he always carries one).  Never mind it's an endangered species, they were LOOKing for a bear (so why no tranq gun?).  And besides all that, how about not superimposing a bad pic that looks stolen from google image search?  And there's the Coast Guard chopper that doesn't ruffle Horatio's hair at all (as it takes off right behind him).  There's the "space tourism" that is a massive shuttle-like spacecraft that stays in space for a week and has airlocks/spacewalks.  Etc, etc.  The further fiction strays from reality, the better quality it has to be to get away with it.  CSI: Miami doesn't have what it takes.There's a lot more "choppy" video sequences using cuts; this stylistic choice seems aimed at disguising the unnatural acting rather than creating energy or compressing "time".There are a lot of episodes in this set, but the production quality is low-- it just looks "cheap" versus the other CSI franchises (ever since about season 4 or 5).  How about cutting a few episodes and focusing on the remaining ones??  There's a 3-episode cross-over included that covers Miami, NY, and Vegas, and the differences I refer to (quality, acting) are starkly apparent.  Maybe 20% of the episodes show some real care in production ("look polished").There are some strengths in the beautiful scenery of Miami's oceanfronts, the cute girls in bikinis, there are unique cases/problems based on local terrain, some opening sequences that remain edgy, and a few moments of strong acting (like Horatio seeing his son off to war).  But the generally weak casting, the painfully simplistic approach to very serious issues of legality and consequences, and the superficial approaches that lead to immediately cracking the case in nearly every episode leave this season barely watchable.With this season, I'm afraid CSI Miami has crossed the line to Not Recommended.
summary: Better writing, but bad acting, remains weakest of the 3 CSI franchises

reviewText: What can I say?  I have fallen in love with Horatio - he can grill me anytime!! Seriously, all 3 series are really very, very good. Each one has it's own particular attraction but they are all well acted, the stories very good and the characters extremely believable. I am sorry that Grissom left because for me he strung the whole unit together. This not to take anything away from Laurence Fishburn who is playing a very believable character, but I do miss Will Peterson. I wait eagerly for each new box set from each of the three series

Not a good man.

reviewText: After ending a pretty great 7th season, Season Eight had turned around 360 and started to disappoint. Two newcomers to the CSI Miami team, Eddie Cibrian as "Jesse Cardoza" and Omar Miller as "Walter Simmons" made little improvement as the cast began to expand while veteran Adam Rodriguez (Eric Delko) appeared off and on in several episodes while filming the final season of Ugly Betty and the film Tyler Perry's "I Can Do Bad All By Myself". This season, the characters explore the world of cougar women, a company's legal terms with insurance policies, a meth lab explosion, a Hannah Montana-like homicide, the murder of an unpopular office receptionist, an arranged marriage gone wrong, a complete crossover of all CSI series including Las Vegas & New York, and a bag of diamonds gone missing from the evidence locker. As lives are threatened, as one of the CSI members gets accused for something they didn't do, as Horatio's son Kyle (played by Evan Ellingson) returns from the war with a personal problem, and a season-ender with everyone in the lab fallen ill, who knows what will come next in Season Nine?
